revision.text:
'''Donald Haderle''' is an American computer scientist and [[IBM Fellow]], best known for his work on [[relational database management system]]s (RDBMS). He led the architecture and design of [[IBM DB2|DB2]], one of the first commercial RDBMSs.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Lai |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/print/9034619/Relational_database_pioneer_says_technology_is_obsolete |title=Relational database pioneer says technology is obsolete |publisher=Computerworld.com |date=2007-09-06 |accessdate=2011-04-19}}</ref> DB2 debuted on [[IBM]]'s [[mainframe computer|mainframe]] system [[MVS]] in 1983 and validated the applicability of relational databases for high performance [[transaction processing]].
Haderle was appointed IBM Fellow in 1989 and was elected to the [[National Academy of Engineering]] in 2008. Before his retirement from IBM in 2005, he was vice president and [[chief technology officer]] for [[information management]]. He received a B.A. degree in economics from the [[University of California Berkeley]] in 1967. He is a [[ACM Fellow|fellow]] of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] (2000).
In August 2012, Haderle joined [[Aerospike (company)]], a company working in a NoSQL Database called [[Aerospike database]] as Technology advisor.<ref>http://www.vcaonline.com/news/news.asp?ID=2012082703#.UOgLpbbfk5w</ref>
